Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the step-parent should attend
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story:
I stared at the calendar, my hand trembling slightly as I traced the date with my finger. Today was the open class at Lily’s school—the first one since I became her stepmother. She had left a note on my pillow last night, her handwriting hopeful: “I hope you can come, it would mean a lot.” I knew how much she needed to see me there, to feel that I was truly part of her life, not just a visitor in her home.

But as I reached for my habit, Sister Maria burst into my room, her face pale. “The Johnsons’ house burned down last night. They have nothing. Mother Superior wants us to gather food and clothes, immediately.” The urgency in her voice was unmistakable. As a nun, I was expected to put the needs of the suffering first, to be present for those in crisis, to serve without hesitation.

My heart pounded as I stood between my two worlds. Lily’s hopeful eyes haunted me, but so did the image of the Johnsons, shivering and lost. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my presence, my compassion, my love.
